item.title: Egypt Cuts Canal Fees to Attract Shipping Amid Trump-Houthi Deal
item.description: Egypt cut fees for some vessels crossing the Suez Canal, seeking to spur a revival of the key global trade route after Donald Trump’s deal to halt Yemeni militant attacks on Red Sea shipping.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Tarek El-Tablawy

media:content.media:description: Ships sail along Egypt's Suez Canal near Ismailia on April 16.

item.title: Ghana’s Mahama Fine Tuning Regime to Accelerate Crude Extraction
item.description: Ghana is encouraging investors to get the country’s crude out of the ground to avoid the assets from getting stranded amid a global decarbonization push.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Zabasajja, Kamailoudini Tagba, Ekow Dontoh

media:content.media:description: John Mahama Photographer: NIPAH DENNIS/AFP

item.title: UN Agency Rules Russia Shot Down Malaysian Jet in 2014
item.description: The UN’s aviation council ruled on Monday that Russia was responsible for the 2014 downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 that killed all 298 passengers and crew, including more than 200 Dutch and Australian citizens.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: GRABOVO, UKRAINE - JULY 22: Wreckage from Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 lies in a field on July 22, 2014 in Grabovo, Ukraine. Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 was travelling from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur when it crashed killing all 298 on board including 80 children. The aircraft was allegedly shot down by a missile and investigations continue over the perpetrators of the attack. (Photo by Rob Stothard/Getty Images)

item.title: China-US Truce Prompts Price Jump in Pacific Shipping Frenzy
item.description: A China-US deal to slash trade tariffs is set to push freight rates higher, as companies rush to use a 90-day grace period to ferry goods across the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Weilun Soon

media:content.media:description: Containers at the Port of Long Beach, California.

item.title: Trump Faces $2 Trillion Hurdle to Win Money From Saudi Prince
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s hopes of securing as much as $1 trillion in investment commitments from Saudi Arabia might clash with another costly ambition - transforming the kingdom’s own economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Martin, Zainab Fattah

media:content.media:description: An illustration of Neom's planned Line Development, provided in March 2024.

item.title: India Proposes First Counter Move Against Trump’s Tariff Regime
item.description: India has proposed levies on some US goods in response to Washington’s duties on steel and aluminum, marking its first retaliation against President Donald Trump’s tariff regime, even as the two countries move closer to finalizing a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A crane is used to load stainless steel coils onto a train container at Jindal Stainless Ltd. plant in Jajpur, Odisha, India, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. India is scheduled to release industrial production figures on April 28. Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

item.title: The Problem With the Fed Isn’t Independence, It’s Accountability
item.description: Monetary policy is too technical to be left to the politicians and too political to be left to the technocrats.
item.dc:creator: Tom Orlik

media:content.media:description: Photographer: Scott Semler for Bloomberg Businessweek. Prop Stylist: Andrea Bonin

item.title: Success of Chinese Jets Against India Raises Alarm in Asia
item.description: The recent conflict between India and Pakistan is prompting a reassessment of Chinese weapons, challenging long-held perceptions of their inferiority to Western arms and sparking concern in places wary of Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: Pakistan Air Force J-10C fighter jets produced by China’s Chengdu Aircraft Company.

item.title: Lula’s China Trip Channels Xi’s Trade Defiance
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Travis Waldron

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping greets Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva after delivering his opening speech for the opening ceremony of the Fourth Ministerial Meeting of the Forum of China and Community of Latin American and Caribbean States in Beijing, on May 13. Photographer: Andy Wong/AP

item.title: Germany Raids Self-Appointed ‘Kingdom’ in Right-Wing Crackdown
item.description: More than 800 German law-enforcement officers took part in raids across the country as part of wider efforts by Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s new administration to crack down on extremism.
item.dc:creator: Karin Matussek, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: 13 May 2025, Thuringia, Gera: Police officers search buildings following the ban of the Reichsbürger group "Kingdom of Germany" by the Federal Minister of the Interior, in Gera, Thuringia, on May 13.

item.title: Marcos-Duterte Feud Spurs Surprise Gains by ‘Third Force’ in Philippine Vote
item.description: Two liberal Philippine politicians have emerged as key players after a surprisingly strong performance in Senate elections, gaining support from a bloc of voters dissatisfied with rancor between President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and his deputy Sara Duterte.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo

media:content.media:description: Francis Pangilinan Photographer: Lauren DeCicca/Getty Images

item.title: Reeves Says Never Say Never on Forcing UK Pension Investment
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves said she didn’t rule out mandating pension funds to allocate money to UK assets, as the government seeks to channel more investment into the domestic economy.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Lizzy Burden

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves Photographer: Tolga Akmen/EPA

item.title: GOP Tax Plan Tilts to Trump Populism But Still Aids the Rich
item.description: Republicans injected some populist elements to their latest draft plan for Donald Trump’s tax cuts, while stopping short of embracing a progressive move the president recently endorsed and failing to silence critics that it ultimately puts the rich ahead.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Cook

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump

item.title: King Charles to Host France’s Macron for First UK State Visit
item.description: King Charles III will host French President Emmanuel Macron for his first state visit to the UK in July, Buckingham Palace said.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: King Charles III and Emmanuel Macron in Woodstock, on July 18.

item.title: Romania Is Headed for Tight Presidential Runoff, Poll Shows
item.description: Romania’s presidential runoff is shaping up to be a tight contest between a far-right party leader poised to upend the Black Sea nation’s pro-European path and a contender promising a more centrist brand of leadership.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan at an electoral rally in Bucharest, Romania, on May 11.

item.title: Hong Kong Rushes Security Law Changes, Cementing Beijing’s Grip
item.description: Hong Kong fast-tracked changes to its national security laws that further consolidate Beijing’s control over the financial hub, with the new regulations taking effect immediately.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong

media:content.media:description: The flag of China on a bridge in Hong Kong. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

item.title: Philippine Voters Boost Duterte Dynasty in Warning for Marcos
item.description: Philippine voters delivered a blow to President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and a boost to the controversial Duterte clan, whose performance in midterm elections Monday shows they may have a chance to regain the nation’s highest office in 2028.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon, Andreo Calonzo

media:content.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. at a polling station in Batac town, Ilocos Norte province, on May 12. Source: STR/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: EU Plagued by ‘Collective Action Problem’ on Trade, Bessent Says
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the European Union suffers from a “collective action problem” that’s hampering trade negotiations, downplaying the possibility of a quick agreement with the US’s largest trading relationship.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: Bessent Is Upbeat on China Trade Talks Thanks to 2020 Framework
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the trade deal from Donald Trump’s first tariff war with China gives the world’s two biggest economies “a very good framework” for upcoming discussions after the temporary lifting of levies between them.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Paul Abelsky

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent at the Saudi-US Investment Forum in Riyadh, on May 13.

item.title: GOP Tax Bill Prioritizes Trump Campaign Vows, Increases SALT
item.description: President Donald Trump’s campaign tax pledges — no taxes on tips and overtime pay, plus new tax breaks for car buyers and seniors — are the centerpiece of a multitrillion dollar package that will serve as Republicans’ signature legislative effort.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Ari Natter, Nancy Cook

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. The legislative push for President Donald Trump's massive tax package will begin in earnest next week as key House committees consider the legislation despite lingering divisions among Republicans. Photographer: Aaron Schwartz/Bloomberg

item.title: India Denies Trump’s Suggestion He Used Trade to Secure Truce
item.description: Indian officials denied that trade with the US was used as a bargaining chip in a just-concluded ceasefire between India and Pakistan, contradicting statements by President Donald Trump that the US offered to trade more with both countries if they stopped hostilities.
item.dc:creator: Santosh Kumar, Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Dan Strumpf

media:content.media:description: An Indian man watches the live telecast of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's speech on television screens, in Prayagraj, in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, India, Monday, May 12, 2025. (AP Photo/Rajesh Kumar Singh) Photographer: Rajesh Kumar Singh/AP

item.title: SALT, Tips and Auto Loans: A Guide to the House GOP Tax Bill
item.description: House Republicans’ release of the tax provisions in their massive fiscal bill provides a crucial initial reading of what party leaders think could pass, culminating weeks of intense negotiations among fractious GOP lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: Customers at a Ford dealership in Richmond, California, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. US retail sales rose substantially in March on a jump in car purchases and other goods such as electronics, suggesting consumers were scrambling to get ahead of tariffs.

item.title: Albanian Premier Boosts Parliament Control With Election Triumph
item.description: Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama cemented his control over parliament at this weekend’s election as voters bought into his pledges to take the nation into the European Union by 2030.
item.dc:creator: Gresa Kraja

media:content.media:description: Edi Rama in Tirana on May 11.

item.title: Thailand Submits Proposals to US to Get Tariff Talks Started
item.description: Thailand has submitted a range of proposals to the US on how it plans to boost imports and promote investments, the latest bid by the Southeast Asian nation to nudge the Trump administration to begin formal talks over a planned 36% tariff on exports.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: A container ship at Bangkok Port.

item.title: Europe Awaits Turkey Summit to Push US on Russian Sanctions
item.description: European leaders are ready to wait until after a possible meeting between Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and Russia’s Vladimir Putin in Turkey before pushing the US to announce fresh sanctions on Moscow, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Alberto Nardelli, Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskiy

item.title: Portuguese Prime Minister’s Coalition Leads in Poll, TVI Reports
item.description: Portuguese Prime Minister Luis Montenegro’s AD coalition led the opposition Socialists by a margin of 6.9 percentage points in an opinion poll, TVI reported on its website.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Luis Montenegro Photographer: Zed Jameson/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Talks With MBS as He Seeks Saudi Investment

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman arrive at Al-Yamamah Palace.

item.title: Xi Courts Latin America as Trump’s Tariffs Pressure Region
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping vowed to deepen economic cooperation with Latin American and Caribbean nations and offered visa-free entry to some countries, as he seeks to position China as a better partner than the US.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Jing Li

media:content.media:description: China's President Xi Jinping speaks during the opening ceremony of the Fourth Ministerial Meeting of the Forum of China and Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC), in Beijing on May 13, 2025. (Photo by Pedro Pardo / AFP) (Photo by PEDRO PARDO/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: China Removes Ban on Boeing Deliveries After US Trade Truce
item.description: China has removed a month-long ban on airlines taking delivery of Boeing Co. planes, according to people familiar with the matter, following a breakthrough in trade talks with the US that temporarily slashed tariffs on each side.
item.dc:creator: Danny Lee

media:content.media:description: An employee works on the wing of a Boeing Next Generation 737 jet on an assembly line at Boeing's manufacturing facility in Renton, Washington, U.S., on Wednesday, Oct. 27, 2010. Boeing Co. kept production of the 737, the world's most widely flown plane, steady through the recession and plans to increase it by more than 20 percent over the span of a year starting in 2012.

item.title: Australia’s Liberal Opposition Elects First Female Leader
item.description: Australia’s center-right Liberal party has elected Sussan Ley as its new leader, the first woman to head the party since it was founded in 1944, taking up the task of leading the opposition back to government after a devastating election loss 10 days ago.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Sussan Ley Photographer: Louise Kennerley/Sydney Morning Herald/Getty Images
